data.title: Best, Brightest and Rejected: Elite Colleges Turn Away Up to 95%

media.caption: Stanford University accepted 5 percent of applicants in the latest admissions season, a new low among elite colleges.
media.copyright: Thor Swift for The New York Times

media.caption: Isaac Madrid, who attends a private high school in San Jose, Calif., applied to 11 colleges and was accepted at Yale.
media.copyright: Thor Swift for The New York Times

media.caption: Students at Yale University last spring. A generation ago, it was rare for even highly competitive colleges to offer places to fewer than 20 percent of their applicants.
media.copyright: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times

media.caption: The campus of Stanford University in Palo Alto, Calif., on Tuesday.
media.copyright: Thor Swift for The New York Times

A Defiant Rancher Savors the Audience That Rallied to His Side

media.caption: Cliven Bundy, flanked by supporters, has become a celebrity, drawing hundreds of sympathizers.
media.copyright: John Locher/Las Vegas Review-Journal, via Associated Press

media.caption: Protesters claiming government overreach in Nevada paused to observe the national anthem.
media.copyright: Jason Bean/Las Vegas Review-Journal, via Associated Press

media.caption: His sympathizers include dozens of militia members, many carrying weapons.
media.copyright: Jim Urquhart/Reuters

media.caption: Sympathizers have embraced Mr. Bundy as a symbol of their anger and a bulwark against federal abuse.
media.copyright: Ronda Churchill for The New York Times

media.caption: The standoff over cattle grazing has highlighted divisions over Washington and its sprawling ownership of Western land.
media.copyright: John Locher/Las Vegas Review-Journal, via Associated Press

data.title: Papyrus Referring to Jesus’ Wife Is More Likely Ancient Than Fake, Scientists Say

media.caption: A fragment of papyrus, known as the “Gospel of Jesus’s Wife,” has been analyzed by professors at Columbia University, Harvard University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who reported that it resembled other ancient papyri.
media.copyright: Karen L. King/Harvard University, via Reuters

Laemmle’s List: A Mogul’s Heroism

media.caption: Carl Laemmle, a founder of Universal Pictures, underwrote or assisted the emigration of many Jews from Germany as the Third Reich grew.

media.caption: Members of the extended Laemmle family, with Carl at center.
media.copyright: Collection of Rosemary Hilb

media.caption: Laemmle with Margaret Apt Weissman, who immigrated to the United States with his help.
media.copyright: Collection of Rosemary Hilb

media.caption: A Laemmle holiday card noting Jews’ plight.
media.copyright: Collection of Rosemary Hilb

media.caption: Policemen at the Berlin premiere of “All Quiet on the Western Front” in 1930.
media.copyright: Imagno/Getty Images

media.caption: Lew Ayres, left, and Raymond Griffith in “All Quiet on the Western Front.”
media.copyright: Film Forum/Photofest

media.caption: Hermann Einstein, whom Laemmle aided.
media.copyright: Courtesy of Sandy Einstein

data.title: Peter Matthiessen, Lyrical Writer and Naturalist, Is Dead at 86

media.caption: The author, at his home in Sagaponack, N.Y., in 2008, won the National Book Award in both fiction and nonfiction.
media.copyright: Gordon M. Grant for The New York Times

media.caption: Peter Matthiessen
media.copyright: Jill Krementz, All Rights Reserved

media.caption: Peter Matthiessen, second from right, with, from left, William Styron, Tom Guinzburg and George Plimpton in 1976.
media.copyright: Jill Krementz, All Rights Reserved

media.caption: Mr. Matthiessen in 1975. His fifth novel, “Far Tortuga,” written that same year, explored Caribbean turtle hunting.
media.copyright: Jill Krementz, All Rights Reserved

media.caption: Peter Matthiessen won a National Book Award for “Shadow Country.”
media.copyright: Fernando Ariza/The New York Times

data.title: In a Hole, Golf Considers Digging a Wider One

media.caption: The tour professional Sergio García putting to a 15-inch hole, one of the changes being tried to make the game more inviting.
media.copyright: Paul Abell/Associated Press for Hack Golf

media.caption: A 15-inch hole could help beginners and older golfers “score better, play faster and like golf more,” Sergio García said.
media.copyright: Paul Abell/Associated Press for Hack Golf
